re-declaration?
Acknowledged
done
Please fix CI failure and update unit test cases
please make sure this D-bus configuration  persists across reboot
why do we need to iterate through userList and set user config??
because we need to do certain things like clearing of google_authenticator files belonging to the user. User manager need not worry about those details. Done for encapsulation.
This method was not present when I did this patch set. Did you add this to Dbus interface?

Also we may have to pass the value flag to the user in case of value is true. We may not have any implementation in googleauthenticator for value true. But in general and in future that may not be true.
There are no D-bus interfaces changes
Done
Please add an inline comment here saying that this uses the google authenticator app to execute this.
Acknowledged
done
Set this to false after the remove is successful.

I am going to remove the call itself. First of all this need not be property. It can be a method instead. It can be implemented by checking presence of authenticator files. It at all it needs to be property then we will mark it as read only property. Then this set call is un necessary . We will only implement get call that return bool that indicates presence of file.
are you saying isSecretKeySetup D-bus method which take username at User-Manager instead of D-bus property at user object?

Nope . I am suggesting isSecretKeySetup as method in User object. We don't have to keep track of property just to check if secret key is setup or not. It will always corresponds to presence of .google_athenticator file in home dir. So make it a method and return value based on the presence of the file will do the job.
I think

I got your point,
for now lets can keep isSecretKeySetup as D-bus property so that redfish events can be sent based on this property change signal.

googleAuthenticatorEnabled is at User-Manager property
dont need to implement for each user
Look at answer above
Done
please add more details on D-bus interfaces gets implemented in this commit
please update commit message with little more details
Done
Please add unit test cases
will do it in different commit
ok
Done
lets have these traces
done
Done
add a comment here saying this rename makes secret key file gets committed
Acknowledged
needed this line to set thisp.isSecretKeySetup to false right?

This is kind of readonly property and it relies always on the presence of secret key file in home dir. I prefer isSecretKeySetup a method.
We don't have to complicate code by having two thing tracking same state.
Done
remove?
Done
Done
can you please if you can put all this MFA code under meson flag?

That make the Interfaces declaration different. Do you want me to put it under compiler directive? Does it break any backward compatibility if we don't do it? If we do it then we have to make sure that bmcweb also uses same flag to enable MFA.
I can do it in different commit in case we need to compile out the mfa implementation
I think persistency of these properties also needs to be taken care right?
Yes but that makes this commit big. Wanted to split it in smaller pieces. Persistency need changes to bring dependency on nlohmann::json
this new commit addresses persistency https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-user-manager/+/74954

can you please populate "Supported" property value with googleAuthenticator

busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.User.Manager /xyz/openbmc_project/user
NAME                         TYPE   SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE               FLAGS
xyz.openbmc_project.User.MultiFactorAuthConfiguration interface -     -                    -
.Enabled                       property s     "xyz.openbmc_project.User.MultiFactor... emits-change writable
.Supported                      property as     0                    emits-change
Done

This commit looks good
Expecting new commits to handle MFA configuration persistency and unit test cases.

CI failed for D-bus interface changes

./users.hpp:141:10: error: ‘bool phosphor::user::Users::isGenerateSecretKeyRequired()’ marked ‘override’, but does not override
  141 |     bool isGenerateSecretKeyRequired() override;
      |       

D-bus commit in review
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/75133

Hi Ratan
Can you please review this commit
This code doesn't seem to even compile.  Is this being worked?

Hi Patrick 

This commit CI was failing for D-bus interface change
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/75133

This commit works with this D-bus interface change
You can use the topic-based testing now.  But I've also left comments a while ago on the dbus interface.  I replied again now.

`find_library` shouldn't be used in Meson unless there is absolutely no other option.

PAM supplies `pam.pc`.  You should be able to use the normal `dependency` directive.

It is inspired from here https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/meson.build#L199 
Let me see if I can use dependency directive
Done
Why are we doing this by default?  Shouldn't we have a PACKAGECONFIG / meson-option that controls this?
Acknowledged
Let's organize this file a bit better.  Maybe a `pam` subdirectory?
Acknowledged
Why are we using PAM return codes?  Does PAM require this?
The caller of this api is trying to use pam module and expecting pam errors.
Done

There sure is a lot of casting here.  Do we really want to turn off the linter errors?  This seems like an indication we have poor programming practices.

Not sure why we're using `reinterpret_cast` instead of `static_cast` here.  This is coming from a `void*`.
Yes this code is mostly interacting with C based pam apis. Most of the conversation involves opaque void* type.
Done

There isn't anything clearer here?

What is a `make_unique` on an unsized C-array doing??
yeah it looks confusing, but valid code. We could have used  std::unique_ptr<pam_response[]> pamArray(new pam_conv[msgCount]); I just followed how it is being used in bmcweb
But why... why can't you use std::vector or std::array?  Between the make_unique and the spans, this is fairly difficult to understand code.

Maybe, but this memory is handed over to to C pam module that  supposed to consume and delete it later. So there is should not be any vector meta data at the beginning( which I am not sure) and the memory should outlive the vector life. We can assume that vector may allocate memory for element storage separately but we cannot make the vector release ownership of its memory as unique ptr do. Even if you know some trick for it I assume it is going to be uglier than this.

> Maybe, but this memory is handed over to to C pam module that supposed to consume and delete it later.

This points to a fundamental aspect that is broken with your code: C code uses `free`, C++ (ex. make_unique) uses `delete`.  You cannot mix these.  If the PAM code is going to call `free` on something you allocated with `make_unique` this is broken.

This code must be changed anyhow.
True. I realised that after writing the previous comment itself. I make those changes. Need to make commit to original source of this code(bmcweb) as well.
Done
NO!  Absolutely not.  Anything in a "details" namespace is meant as a private implementation detail.

Are you suggesting to hardcode the enums instead of getting it from generated file?That is not good for maintenance, when in future if new enum gets added to the interface. Why can't we move out the enum list(mappingMultiFactorAuthConfigurationType) from detail namespace? or is there any other way to get the list of enums in public namespace?

Across the project "details" is an indication that this is a private API that is not to be used outside of the repository and can change at any time.  You may not use an sdbusplus "details" namespace.

If you think it is helpful for this to be exposed as a map of some sort, please make a change proposal to sdbusplus' generator for `common.hpp`.
Done
static??
Done
static constexpr?
Is there any strong reason to start with a `string_view` on these?  `auto` seems just as reasonable.
Acknowledged

There is an inconsistency in code review across repos. Someone will say  use auto others say be explicit about types. In this case I prefer being explicit. Don't know what benefit we get if we use auto.

But why use a `string_view` and not a C-string (which is the default from an `auto`)?

With `string_view` you're explicitly constructing something which is not guaranteed to be NUL terminated.  Since you're just using it as arguments to functions that can just as easily accept a C-string, it seems like extra hoops for no benefit.
Acknowledged
This is C++.  `struct` here isn't necessary.
Acknowledged
Why are we checking specifically for GoogleAuthenticator here?  That's surprising.

We started the implementation in very generic way. Both in interface and implementation side(Redfish/Dbus). But we got comments saying that just do it for google authenticator now and that is the most likely supported only mfa in BMC

Do you have references to this discussion?  It doesn't seem like that should be an excuse to make it very difficult to add another type in the future.  You've basically embedded GoogleAuthenticator stuff everywhere.

The discussion was in the Dbus interface definition commit. If interested you can go down some earlier patch set of this commit to see how the implementation was altered. Anyway let me try to make the implementation generic.
Acknowledged
We really shouldn't be creating a bunch of new InternalFailures.  This is a dbus anti-pattern.

What you suggest? If user calls createSecretKey on MFA disabled system what error we should generate? I believe you had suggestion for not to invent any new error for MFA in the Dbus interface review .
Acknowledged
I realize now that you're returning empty strings all over.  Shouldn't we give a proper error response to the dbus request?

Please say what you have in mind. And how the return value propagated to the caller if there is an elog<...> proceed with it? I could see a pattern in calling side where caller just checks the error_code and returns from there with out reading anything else.

I don't really know what you're trying to accomplish.  Why did you even use `elog`?  That just logs an event directly to phosphor-logging and doesn't return it on dbus.

You've now created magic values that the users have to understand (which are entirely undocumented).

If you've reached a condition where you can't proceed with what the user requested you need to tell the user.

(*) By "user" I mean caller of your dbus interface.

I see that elog throws https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/lib/include/phosphor-logging/elog.hpp#L187 , which is strange for a logging api. 

Anyway, I assumed after seeing the elog<..>() usage elsewhere in the code, it is the way to return error code back to the caller. Somewhere up in the call stack some code will catch the exception and convert it back to proper error code for the caller. In that case what we return does not matter. I did not see any other pattern to report error back to the user elsewhere in this repo. If I am not right please point me towards right usage pattern.

`elog` throws.  The sdbusplus generated bindings catch whichever exceptions are specified in your phosphor-dbus-interfaces interface and turn them into a dbus error response.

If you are doing that, the empty return is probably not necessary because the code is going to throw anyhow.  `elog` is already marked `[[noreturn]]`.

Please remove the spurious returns because they are adding confusion.

Except...

Your PDI interfaces for this method doesn't have a single error defined.  Therefore, the binding generator isn't going to insert code for any of the catch -> error response stuff I mentioned above.  By calling `elog` you are going to crash your daemon rather than give an error back to the user.  Maybe that is appropriate.

Ok , I was not aware of the try catch insertion by the generator part. Will modify the interface accordingly. 
Yes, the returns are unnecessary anyway.

yes, this method doesn't have any error defined,
I have tried to add few errors to handle these cases in this commit
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72602/11/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/User/GoogleAuthenticator.interface.yaml#17

Can we add some D-bus errors to handle these cases?

> Can we add some D-bus errors to handle these cases?

As long as they are issues your caller can do something about.  We should not be adding new cases of "InternalFailure" for dbus interfaces.

"NotSupported" is fine, for example, since this is something that indicates "you called this code when you shouldn't have".  "InternalFailure" does not tell the caller anything that they can do; reboot the BMC?
Done
Again, you've specified only Google here in a generic file.  Please organize this more modularly to make life easier for the next person who goes to add a new one.
I am not know how do we make this general, because I don't know what options are available for creating secret key for next one.
Acknowledged
This is certainly not an InternalFailure.  This is "not supported", right?
You mean elog<NotSupported> should be used instead?

I don't any common error called "not supported"
shall we add NotSupported D-bus error?
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/83a67417d4fd4f56638701473dc6beae6954e3d2/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Common.errors.yaml#L19
Done
I have absolutely no idea why this is in "verify" and not in "createSecretKey".

Hmm. This needs some explanation about the process of generating secret key and commit to it after making sure that the user has already secured it in his authenticator app. 

MFA is enabled for a user once a secret key file is generated in users home directory. Once it is present in home directory then there is no going back. User must always supply TOPTP to login. This can create a potential lock out scenario.
If the file has been saved in home directory on a generated secret key call and  if user fails to secure the secret key in his mobile app(due to various reasons) then he can no longer login to BMC as he need to supply the TOTP for login.

This verify OTP path give user two stage process to generated secret key.   
1) User calls generate secret key -> bmc generate secret key in a tmp file and returns secret string to the user.
2) User on receiving secret key will capture it in his mobile app.
3) User will confirm to the BMC that he has secret key secured by calling verify TOTP method by supplying a TOTP generated with the secret key.
4) BMC on successful verification of the TOTP will commit to the secret key file by moving it to its actual secret key path.

Moving files randomly in `verifyOTP` is non-intuitive.  At a minimum it needs comments.

Considering `VerifyOTP` could be called N number of times but `CreateSecretKey` is called once, I still don't understand how this rename here is appropriate.
VerifyOtp will be called only once , which is after creating a new secretKey. Ideally the name should have been confirmSecretkey.
Done
Don't use "what" in lg2.  It automatically does conversion for exceptions.
You mean I should remove the {CODE} form the log?
No. I mean you should use `e` and not `e.what()`.
Done

We don't want save any state in DBus. The isSecretKeySetup is derived its value from the presence of google authenticator file in his home directory. Actually isSecretKeySetup need not be a property, it should be a method.
You left commented out code in here.  I have no idea what the purpose of it is.  If this is a hint of some state, use some words to tell me that (also).
Done
Why not use a map?

Problem is If I use map the question I get is why not array?. May be having a uniform rule across repos will be helpful. The reasoning here for array is that the number of handlers are not going to change runtime. 
A quick check here https://godbolt.org/z/zzPdnozW3 reveals that the code generated is lesser for array. Plus there are some runtime efficiency in indexing array(especially when it is smaller). I don't have any particular opinion here. If you still want me to change I can change it. But please make sure that there is uniform guide line for it in OpenBmc , otherwise people contributing to multiple repos will get confused by the maintainers opinionated comments.

We should always be favoring readability over premature optimization.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/1a4f060bd986299ee1f4527ae3c70e0a1e77a250/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#L23

These guidelines are written in order.

> please make sure that there is uniform guide line for it in OpenBmc

We can never write an exhaustive "style" guide; you'll find even the kernel doesn't have one.

If you feel there are certain points of contention that come up regularly, _you_ can suggest improvements to the style guide.
Done

Prefer to use [here][2] bookmark syntax rather than spanning a URL over multiple lines.
